summary: Herbert Itkin was a person of interest due to alleged Mafia connections, espionage activities, and claims of providing information to U.S. intelligence agencies, including the CIA and FBI. He was used as an informant on Haitian exiles. He attempted to involve the CIA in a custody battle, which exposed CIA agent Bernard E. Moncure. Australian Justice A.R. Moffitt sought information on Itkin, described as a former CIA and FBI employee, for an inquiry into organized crime in New South Wales. Itkin claimed CIA involvement and possible connections to Allen Dulles. The documents also mention a confrontation with the New York FBI office regarding Itkin, and requests for information on Thomas L. Roberts and Robert Delson, who have connections to the CIA and Itkin.
significance: The documents suggest Herbert Itkin was a complex figure with alleged ties to organized crime and intelligence agencies. His claims of CIA involvement and connections to Allen Dulles, along with his use as an informant, raise questions about the nature and extent of his activities and potential knowledge of sensitive information. The documents do not directly link Itkin to the JFK assassination, but his connections to intelligence agencies and organized crime could be relevant in understanding the broader context of the assassination.
